The picturesque hill station of Manali has loads to offer through the seasons, and now is the best time to experience the destination in all its glory. We've rounded up a list of resorts, hotels and homestays in and around Manali for your next getaway.Best places to stay in ManaliVastiMohit SrivastavaVasti means ‘home’ in Sanskrit, and that is an apt name for host Mayuri Sinha’s charming homestay in the quiet village of Bathar, sandwiched between Manali and Naggar. The red-and-orange roofed cottage set against the mountains is a safe space for travellers to experience slow, deliberate living in the hills. “We want this place to feel like a home. We do not operate like a typical business. Our homestay is only listed on Airbnb and we are also selective about who we allow into our space,” says Sinha, adding that women travellers and families are prioritised. Set amidst apple orchards, Vasti is located about 11kms away from the Mall Road in Manali in Bathar village. Sinha wanted a space that wasn't too far from Manali and yet offered an escape from the crowds. The two-storeyed wood and stone structure has three guest bedrooms, a living room and dining space, a kitchen garden, and a studio where travellers can dabble in pottery or paint on canvas. On the lower floor is a room that Sinha generally lets out to women travellers during off-season months, as the host herself lives in the same space. The cuisine is largely homestyle, with both vegetarian and non-vegetarian thalis on offer. There's also an option to sample Pahadi cuisine with siddu (steamed bun with walnut filling), madra (a yoghurt-based curry) and Pahadi-style veggies or meat. There are several walking trails and hikes, ranging from easy 20-minute strolls to hour-and-a-half walks to gurgling forest streams. For an immersion in Himachali culture, walk through the Bathar village and have lunch at a local’s home. -Geetika SachdevDoubles from Rs7,000*/night inclusive of taxes (for the room on the lower floor); Rs 20,000*/night inclusive of taxes for the entire cottage. Minimum stay two nights.plan your stayHunzuruYash JainSituated in Pangan, a hamlet within Manali but distanced from the town's more crowded areas, Hunzuru is a consciously designed homestay built out of mud and stone. The five-bedroom homestay is built with the wabi-sabi philosophy that celebrates imperfections. Expect stone walls, handcrafted furniture, and muted natural colours across the 3,500sqft space that’s spread across three levels. Large windows open to panoramic mountain views throughout the house. There’s plenty to do in and around the homestay. Drive through the Atal Tunnel to Sissu or to the busier parts of Manali for some shopping or cute cafés, enjoy hikes to nearby waterfalls and villages, or take a day trip to Naggar.Doubles from Rs6,299plan your stayHygge HouseThe quaint four-bedroom cottage—solely for exclusive bookings—sits in the serene setting of Raison, steeped in the pastoral charm of the surrounding fruit farm and a cluster of villages on the banks of the Beas River, about 27km (an hour’s drive) from Manali. When you enter, you immediately notice the array of panoramic windows throughout the home, which might as well be postcards, framing the picturesque Pir Panjal range of the Lower Himalayas from ample angles; the mountains whispering for you to unwind in this kind cradle of pristine nature. The two-storey cottage is rustic, yet it is imbued with a healthy dash of understated elegance in its open-plan living and dining rooms, floor-to-ceiling windows with views of the orchard and mountains, and a wrap-around verandah and an open-air sit-out surrounded by fruit trees. The bedrooms feature unique touches that distinguish them, and each is named after a flower that grows on the property: Tulip and Iris are on the ground level, while Daffodil and Bluebell are on the first floor. Breakfast is complimentary and lunch and dinner are served on request. Highlights from Hygge House’s food offerings are the egg masala curry, kadai chicken, bhature served with bhaji, kadhi pakora, rajma chawal, matar paneer, and the Himachali dham. Guests can explore the surrounding villages and towns or relax at the property with books and board games. Spend your time spotting birds like red-billed blue magpies or Himalayan bulbul at the property, tour the orchard, or enjoy a lazy picnic lunch by the river. Pallavi MehraHygge House is only rented out in its entirety. The tariff per night is Rs30,000 for up to six guests and Rs36,000 for eight guests.Sitara HimalayaHimanshu Lakhwani Ever the creative, Anita Lal, founder of India’s iconic lifestyle brand Good Earth, channelled her alchemist’s heart into a new 10-bedroom garden retreat immersed in the spiritual magnitude of the Himalayas last year. Sitara Himalaya is located at an altitude of 8,200 feet, 13km (about a 90-minute drive) from Manali, on the way to the ancient Buddhist valleys of Lahaul and Spiti. Ten spacious bedrooms (five downstairs, five upstairs) are covered in varying shades of a hand-spun Banarasi silk wallpaper depicting a sacred Buddhist motif of a Himalayan cloud. Up in the clouds is where guests sleep. Opening the curtains to a view of snow-capped peaks and the purity of light and air is an immediate uplift. Don’t expect room service menus, mini-bars, or TVs. Instead, there’s a dedicated library space, painted in teal and sky blue with red accents in homage to Buddhist monasteries. One gets the feeling you could settle into a new way of life here. Read a little more, sleep a little more, dream a little more, do nothing a little more. Daisy FinerDoubles from Rs90,000 for a minimum three-night stay, which includes transfers from Kullu’s Bhuntar Airport and all meals, excursions, laundry and beveragesRaison D'être, ManaliIndoor seating areasRaison D'être is Shalini and Nitin Beri’s dream home. Perched amidst sunflowers next to the Beas River, this house is divided into a four-bedroom guest house and the couple’s private living quarters. In the middle stands a vibrant garden with fruit trees and blooming flowers. Inside, each room has its own character with artwork collected by the owners. But look out, and you’ll see the biggest piece of art: a sparkling river contrasted by pines and snow-capped mountains. A Himalayan aquifer some hundreds of feet below feeds everything here, including the infinity pool perfect for a cool dip in the summers. Meals are always served alfresco under an apricot tree every day, except when it may be snowing or raining. But with a sunny atmosphere and ample greenery around, there are hardly days when you can’t enjoy the great outdoors. Doubles from Rs7,499*.BOOK A STAYTree of Life Eila Art Hotel, NaggarDeep within the deodar forests of Naggar, touched only by the sound of a gushing Beas in the distance, a gate done up in gold foil and vibrant colours welcomes you into this 10-key property. Most rooms here look out to the Dhauladhar mountains. While some are done up in contemporary art, others boast skylights or a convenient proximity to the hotel’s pool. During the day, the team will set up local treks for you, plan a fishing trip to the river or drive you to a nearby sunset point for an evening of soaking in great Himalayan views. The menu features Gujarati, Continental, North Indian and Rajasthani cuisines along with the Himachali dham. You can choose to take your meals in the restaurant, or in the sit-out area with a valley view. Doubles from Rs13,900* including breakfast.BOOK A STAYThe Luxurious Penthouse, NaggarWarm wooden interiors contrast the cool blue view at this three-bedroom homestay in Naggar. Sizeable windows look out to fruit trees, flowers and snow-capped Himalayas. Guests are given access to two full bedrooms, an attic room, attached bathrooms, a living room, a fully-functional private kitchen and a dining room, a powder room and private balconies. Chandan, the host, will set up trekking and fishing trips for you and even set up a bonfire at an additional cost. Entire penthouse from Rs15,000* for six people including meals.BOOK A STAYHBA Homestay, NaggarThis one is for travellers looking to immerse in the simple joys of Himachali living. Some 20km from Manali, this homestay in Naggar sits among apple orchards and vegetable gardens. All rooms open to mountain views, and the entire home is kept warm with a pahadi tandoor. You can book a room for two, or an entire loft house for a larger party of six. Cosy up in the stone-and-wood setting, or perch in your private balcony for a taste of the outdoors. Doubles from Rs1,600*.BOOK A STAYThe Himalayan, ManaliLocated in Kullu Valley, this castle resort sits at an elevation of over 2,000 metres. What sets it apart is its Victorian and gothic-style architecture, complete with antique furniture, medieval arches and cast-iron fireplaces. You can choose from accommodation like the chambers, tastefully done up with hardwood floors, antique poster beds, a fireplace and an en-suite marble bathroom; and the charming two-bedroom cottages strung around the pool and the orchard garden with private balconies overlooking the majestic Himalayas. The best views though, are to be found from the Crow's Nest, the castle's highest vantage point, offering 360-degree views of the surrounding landscape. The resort also offers seasonal activities such as hiking, trekking and camping. Doubles from Rs9,900* per night.BOOK A STAYThe Taara House, ManaliThis boutique two-bedroom mountain lodge nestled on a hilltop and located just a few kilometres away from Manali's city centre makes for a rustic getaway in the mountains. Scandinavian light fixtures and local artefacts add to the eclectic vibe of this space, along with extensive use of recycled and reclaimed wood. But the real showstopper here is the glasshouse, where you can dine under the stars or simply soak in the sun. A lot of the wooden interiors have been fashioned using pine, English oak and Burma Teak, especially across the hall and in the spacious rooms that can host up to four guests. With the reserve pine forest on one end and the mountain ranges on the other, the Taara House makes for a picture-perfect retreat or a base for your workcation in Manali. Entire lodge from Rs18,000* per night with a minimum stay of two nights.BOOK A STAYStorii by ITC Hotels Urvashi's Retreat, ManaliLocated in the picturesque environs of Bipasha valley, this boutique property that doubles as a nature retreat offers rooms, cottages and villas with chalet-style interiors, perfect for a cosy winter getaway. Definitely try the special pahaari dham menu, which is a modern rendition of traditional Himachali staples, think, gahat ka shorba (lentil soup), laung pulao, maash dal (black lentil dal), kaddu ka khatta (pumpkin curry), among other dishes. You can also enjoy evening suppers and breakfasts at Rohtang Pavillion, the property's dining hall. Doubles from Rs9,850* including breakfast.BOOK A STAYShivAdya, ManaliAn hour away from Kullu-Manali Airport, you can make yourself at home at this  15-bedroom boutique resort in Karjan village. The rooms here have been crafted using locally-sourced stone, mud and wood. All have traditional wooden ceilings and some offer private sit-outs as well. Each of these rooms are named after local villages or mountain ranges. Keeping in mind its ecological footprint, the resort heats all the water using solar energy and collects rainwater for gardening. What's more, the resort organises nature walks through apple orchards or mountain biking activities, to soak in the charm of staying in this hill resort town. Doubles from Rs12,800*.BOOK A STAYThe Anantmaya Resort, ManaliSurrounded by orchards and fields with its own landscaped gardens, The Anantmaya Resort with its Tudor-style architecture makes for a plush escape in the mountains. Its 42 contemporary-style luxury and villa rooms offer private balconies and ample space. Situated on Naggar Road, the resort is in close proximity to Naggar Castle and the Jagatsukh Temple, in case you're looking to do some sightseeing in the area. Doubles from Rs12,500* including breakfast.BOOK A STAYJodhpur House, ManaliLocated some 1,000 metres above the bustling streets of Manali, this three-bedroom villa looks out to the Pir Panjal mountains in the front and the Dhauladhar range at the back. It’s perfect for a stay with a group of friends or family–you can gather in the cosy living room with a functional fireplace and enjoy the scenery in the garden right outside your villa. The property is also surrounded by an apple, pear and cherry orchard. Entire place from Rs22,600* including breakfast.BOOK A STAYBaragarh Resort & Spa, Manali by IHCL SeleQtionsImmerse yourself in serenity at this luxury resort and spa in the lap of the Himalayas. There are 33 suites here, each offering stunning vistas from your private balcony. When you're not cocooned in your room with a book or simply taking in the views, head to the property's heated swimming pool which looks out to snow-capped mountains, making for a surreal getaway. Doubles from Rs13,500* including breakfast.BOOK A STAYThe Duffdun House, ManaliKanika Bansal www.kanikabansal.comBreathe in the crisp mountain air at this boutique property in Manali. You can indulge in home-cooked meals using locally-sourced ingredients, and make the most of the many nooks and corners that the house affords or simply laze away afternoons reading a book under the shade of the walnut tree.This six-bedroom villa can accommodate up to 20 guests. Each individual room has its own unique character and colour, from the boutique rooms to the family suite, making it a home away from home in the hills.The property can be booked as a whole or on a per room basis. Doubles from Rs4,000* including breakfast.BOOK A STAY*Prices are subject to change.All products are independently selected by our editors.
